reasoning:
The critique targets a fairly central step in the essay’s case against widespread/accurate/motivational convergence: the §2.4.2 claim that antirealism/subjectivist idealization implies major divergence due to many free parameters. If the critique succeeded, it would weaken the essay’s pessimism about convergence under antirealism, and thereby shift probability mass toward WAM-convergence (and reduce reliance on the §3 “trade/compromise” route). However, the essay’s overall stance also leans on other considerations (realism-to-motivation gap, blockers, threat dynamics), so this is not fully load-bearing.

On strength: it’s a substantive gap-spotting objection—coordination pressures, bargaining equilibria, and focal points can generate convergence without objective moral facts, and the essay itself emphasizes conformity incentives and bargaining elsewhere, which makes the omission somewhat salient. Still, it only partially undercuts the essay’s argument: (i) convergence to stable conventions is not obviously the same as convergence to the very specific, “mostly-great” target the authors care about; (ii) coordination-driven convergence may select for legibility/legitimacy/peace rather than for what any given idealized preference ranking would treat as near-best; and (iii) the essay can reply that such attractors might still leave large axiology-relevant variance (or converge on a compromise that is far from near-best under many views).

Correctness is fairly high: the claimed convergence forces are real and relevant, but the critique somewhat overstates how strongly they ‘collapse’ moral space and how directly they induce convergence on an idealization procedure (instrumental coordination may yield compliance without deep motivational/reflective convergence). The critique is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Coordination pressures can drive convergence even under subjective idealization, contrary to free-parameter overreach
